title: Analyzing the Local Law 97 of 2021-Pets in Shelter Report
text: New York City serves large diverse population, including individuals families experience housing instability may rely homeless shelters temporary support. Pets serve many important role people’s lives, understanding pet ownership among shelter entrants helps inform shelter policy, access services, resource planning. Local Law 97 2021 – Pets Shelter Report provides quarterly survey data types pets owned people entering New York City homeless shelters.dataset recently added NYC Open Data made publicly available October 14, 2025. data published NYC Open Data available . nycOpenData package provides streamlined interface accessing New York City’s open data resources directly R. using nyc_locallaw97_shelter_pets() function, can retrieve recent quarterly shelter pet data explore trends pet ownership across time using familiar data analysis tools.

title: Analyzing the Local Law 97 of 2021-Pets in Shelter Report
text: Now ’ve successfully pulled data R, let’s quick mini analysis look number shelter entrants reported pets changes time. , ’ll create simple bar chart showing number applicants pets year. Bar chart showing number shelter applicants pets year. graph shows number shelter entrants reporting pets changes across years, can help highlight broader trends guide planning pet-related shelter resources.
code: pets <- nyc_locallaw97_shelter_pets(limit = 100) pets$had_pet <- as.numeric(pets$had_pet)  # Summarize by year pet_by_year <- pets %>%   group_by(date_year) %>%   summarize(applicants_with_pets = sum(had_pet, na.rm = TRUE))  # Plot ggplot(pet_by_year, aes(x = date_year, y = applicants_with_pets)) +   geom_col(fill = "darkseagreen") +   theme_minimal() +   labs(     title = "Shelter Applicants With Pets by Year (NYC)",     subtitle = "Local Law 97 - Pets in Shelter Report",     x = "Year",     y = "Number of Applicants With Pets"   )

title: New York City Population by Borough 1950 - 2040
text: New York City made five boroughs: Bronx, Brooklyn, Manhattan, Queens, Staten Island. population boroughs varied throughout past century. nyc_borough_population() function provides access historical census data population projections 1950 2040, allowing one analyze demographic trends across Brooklyn, Bronx, Manhattan, Queens, Staten Island. nycOpenData package provides streamlined interface accessing New York City’s vast open data resources. connects directly NYC Open Data Portal. currently utilized primary tool teaching data acquisition Reproducible Research Using R, helping students bridge gap raw city APIs tidy data analysis.

title: New York City Population by Borough 1950 - 2040
text: Let’s start pulling small sample see structure:
code: small_sample <- nyc_borough_population(limit = 5) small_sample #> # A tibble: 5 × 22 #>   age_group        borough        `_1950` _1950_boro_share_of_nyc_tota…¹ `_1960` #>   <chr>            <chr>          <chr>   <chr>                          <chr>   #> 1 Total Population "NYC Total"    7891957 100.00                         7781984 #> 2 Total Population "   Bronx"     1451277 18.39                          1424815 #> 3 Total Population "   Brooklyn"  2738175 34.70                          2627319 #> 4 Total Population "   Manhattan" 1960101 24.84                          1698281 #> 5 Total Population "   Queens"    1550849 19.65                          1809578 #> # ℹ abbreviated name: ¹​`_1950_boro_share_of_nyc_total` #> # ℹ 17 more variables: `_1960_boro_share_of_nyc_total` <chr>, `_1970` <chr>, #> #   `_1970_boro_share_of_nyc_total` <chr>, `_1980` <chr>, #> #   `_1980_boro_share_of_nyc_total` <chr>, `_1990` <chr>, #> #   `_1990_boro_share_of_nyc_total` <chr>, `_2000` <chr>, #> #   `_2000_boro_share_of_nyc_total` <chr>, `_2010` <chr>, #> #   `_2010_boro_share_of_nyc_total` <chr>, `_2020` <chr>, …  # Seeing what columns are in the dataset colnames(small_sample) #>  [1] "age_group"                     "borough"                       #>  [3] "_1950"                         "_1950_boro_share_of_nyc_total" #>  [5] "_1960"                         "_1960_boro_share_of_nyc_total" #>  [7] "_1970"                         "_1970_boro_share_of_nyc_total" #>  [9] "_1980"                         "_1980_boro_share_of_nyc_total" #> [11] "_1990"                         "_1990_boro_share_of_nyc_total" #> [13] "_2000"                         "_2000_boro_share_of_nyc_total" #> [15] "_2010"                         "_2010_boro_share_of_nyc_total" #> [17] "_2020"                         "_2020_boro_share_of_nyc_total" #> [19] "_2030"                         "_2030_boro_share_of_nyc_total" #> [21] "_2040"                         "_2040_boro_share_of_nyc_total"

title: New York City Population by Borough 1950 - 2040
text: Let’s visualize population trends across boroughs. First, need reshape data wide long format: ## Mini analysis Let’s visualize population trends across boroughs. First, need reshape data wide long format: Population trends NYC’s five boroughs 1950 2040, including historical data projections. can also look borough projected largest population 2040:
code: # Get full dataset and filter for Total Population rows only population_data <- nyc_borough_population()  # Clean borough names and filter to get individual boroughs (exclude NYC Total) borough_data <- population_data %>%   mutate(borough = trimws(borough)) %>%  # Remove leading/trailing spaces   filter(age_group == "Total Population", borough != "NYC Total")  # Reshape from wide to long format pop_long <- borough_data %>%   select(borough, `_1950`, `_1960`, `_1970`, `_1980`, `_1990`, `_2000`, `_2010`, `_2020`, `_2030`, `_2040`) %>%   pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("_"), names_to = "year", values_to = "population") %>%   mutate(     year = as.numeric(gsub("_", "", year)),     population = as.numeric(population)   )  # Create line chart ggplot(pop_long, aes(x = year, y = population, color = borough)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1) +   geom_point(size = 2) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   theme_minimal() +   labs(     title = "NYC Population by Borough: 1950-2040",     subtitle = "Historical data and projections",     x = "Year",     y = "Population",     color = "Borough"   ) +   theme(legend.position = "bottom") pop_long %>%   filter(year == 2040) %>%   arrange(desc(population)) #> # A tibble: 5 × 3 #>   borough        year population #>   <chr>         <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 Brooklyn       2040    2840525 #> 2 Queens         2040    2412649 #> 3 Manhattan      2040    1691617 #> 4 Bronx          2040    1579245 #> 5 Staten Island  2040     501109

title: Getting Started with nycOpenData: data set titled NYPD Shooting Incident Data
text: Since successfully pulled data, lets quick analysis see location (name column: LOC_OF_OCCUR_DESC, Either:Outside inside) shooting incidents borough (name column: BORO). , create cluster bar graph. Cluster bar graph showing shooting incidents per borough based location shooting. graphs shows us counts shooting incidents took place borough based location incident (inside outside)
code: shooting_data<-nyc_shooting_incidents(limit=1000)  ggplot(shooting_data, aes(boro, fill = loc_of_occur_desc)) +   geom_bar(position = "dodge") +   geom_text(     stat = "count",     aes(label=after_stat(count)),     position = position_dodge(width = 0.8),     vjust=-0.2,     size = 3) +   labs(     title = "Counts For Shooting Incidents",     x="Borough",     y="counts of shooting incidents"   )+   theme_minimal()

title: Analyzing NYC Climate Projections: Extreme Events and Sea Level Rise
text: vignette demonstrates use nyc_events_sealevel function explore projected extreme climate events sea level rise New York City. dataset provides projections different climate scenarios, including: - Number heatwaves per year - Cooling heating degree days - Projected sea level rise Researchers, city planners, policymakers can use information understand future climate risks, prepare extreme weather events, plan adaptation strategies.

title: Analyzing NYC Climate Projections: Extreme Events and Sea Level Rise
text: Period=climate period (e.g., “Baseline”, “2030s”) number_of_heatwaves_year=projected heatwaves per year cooling_degree_days/heating_degree_days=metrics temperature extremes table gives quick overview projected extreme events different scenarios.

title: Analyzing NYC Climate Projections: Extreme Events and Sea Level Rise
text: plot shows number heatwaves projected change across scenarios. helps visualize future climate risks glance.
code: ggplot(sample_data, aes(x = period, y = as.numeric(number_of_heatwaves_year))) +   geom_col() +   labs(     title = "Projected Number of Heatwaves by Scenario",     x = "Climate Scenario",     y = "Number of Heatwaves"   ) +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

title: Working With NYC Wetlands Data
text: Let’s create summary table showing many wetland features verified year: Verified Wetland Features Per Year Let’s create bar graph see many wetlands classification verified!  Though vignette demonstrates simple use function, inclusion geospatial data allows users map wetland features using provided multipolygon coordinates.
code: verified_per_year <- verified_wetlands %>%    group_by(verificationstatusyear) %>%    count(verificationstatusyear)  verified_per_year %>% kable(caption = "Verified Wetland Features Per Year") ggplot(data = verified_wetlands, aes(x = classname)) +   geom_bar(fill = "forestgreen") +   labs(title = "Total Number of Wetland Features By Classification", x = "Classification Name", y = "Total Count") +   theme_minimal()

title: Convenient Access to NYC Open Data API Endpoints

title: Convenient Access to NYC Open Data API Endpoints
text: nycOpenData makes New York City’s civic datasets accessible students, educators, analysts, researchers unified user-friendly R interface. Developed support reproducible research, open-data literacy, real-world analysis.

title: Convenient Access to NYC Open Data API Endpoints
text: RSocrata package provides general interface Socrata-backed portal, nycOpenData specifically tailored New York City ecosystem. Ease Use: need hunt 4x4 dataset IDs (e.g., erm2-nwe9); functions like nyc_311() map directly popular city datasets. Pre-configured Logic: Wrappers include default sorting (e.g., created_date DESC) optimized limit handling specific NYC’s massive data volumes. Open Literacy: Designed specifically students researchers lower barrier entry civic data analysis.

title: Convenient Access to NYC Open Data API Endpoints
text: package developed primary pedagogical tool teaching data acquisition open science practices Brooklyn College, City University New York (CUNY).

title: Summary
text: nycOpenData package provides unified, tidy interface New York City Open Data portal. wrapping 40 distinct municipal datasets—ranging 311 service requests Department Buildings job applications—package abstracts complexities SODA (Socrata Open Data API) consistent set R functions. function returns standardized tibble, supporting seamless integration tidyverse-based data science workflows.

title: Summary
text: New York City maintains one comprehensive open data portals world. However, researchers students often face barriers accessing data, including navigating diverse endpoint identifiers, managing API rate limits, cleaning raw JSON responses. general-purpose Socrata wrappers exist, require users manually specify API endpoints handle domain-specific data types. nycOpenData addresses challenges providing curated wrappers high-impact datasets used urban research. package currently core pedagogical component curriculum ‘Reproducible Research Using R’, serves primary tool teaching automated data acquisition. 500 downloads date, package demonstrated significant utility academic practitioner environments.

title: Summary
text: Curated Access: Wrappers 40+ datasets including TLC records, crime statistics, environmental data. Reproducibility: Integrated vcr package mocked HTTP testing, allowing research pipelines verified offline. Tidy Format: Every function ensures date-time strings, numeric values, logical flags correctly parsed R types upon arrival.

title: nycOpenData 0.1.5
text: Added new vignette, “Working NYC 311 Data”, demonstrating end--end, reproducible workflow accessing, filtering, visualizing NYC 311 service requests using nyc_311(). vignette available package website via vignette("nyc-311", package = "nycOpenData"). Updated nyc_311() explicitly target NYC 311 Service Requests dataset covering 2020–present, aligning function current primary NYC Open Data endpoint. Added new function, nyc_311_2010_2019(), providing access historical NYC 311 service request data 2010–2019, maintained separate dataset NYC Open Data platform.
